docTitle.titlePart: Speech to the Hong Kong Family Planning Association

sourceDesc.bibl: Family Planning: Mrs. Margaret Sanger's Lecture on Birth Control, South China Morning Post, Nov. 12, 1952

docBody.head: FAMILY PLANNING: Mrs. Margaret Sanger's Lecture On Birth Control

p.q: A plea for birth control as the most practical means for regulating population in accordance with economics and hygiene was made by Mrs Margaret Sanger, internationally-famous authority on the subject, in a lecture sponsored by the Hongkong Family Planning Association at St. John's Cathedral Hall yesterday.

More than 200 people packed the limited hall to hear her view on the controversial subject. Mrs. Sanger is en route to Bombay to attend the Third International Conference on Planned Parenthood to be held later this month.

In the talk she repeated most of the opinions she has held for a number of years, and which she had occasion recently to expound in Japan. She based her argument on the fact that the conception of life was a great responsibility, entailing care on the part of parents to plan their families instead of proceeding about it in a haphazard fashion.

She described birth control as the conscious control of the birth rate by means of prevention of conception, in accordance with the fundamental need to consider the mother's heath, the father's economic potentialities, the environment of the offspring and their proper place in society.

Mrs. Sanger denied the argument of some religious circles who claimed that birth control meant the murder of children. She said that prevention of conception involved no interference with life, as no life began until conception had taken place. This was strictly in accordance with the facts of biology.

She said she was delighted to note the sound organisation and leadership of the Hongkong Family Planning Association because of the significant nature of its work, and appealed for more support for it. Every individual had a responsibility in the movement for birth control, she declared, because family planning could well be the foundation of society.

She deplored the current trend towards over-population with its attendant deterioration of national health and hygiene, poising the inference that birth control really meant a striving for better national welfare.

Mrs. Sanger said that in the case of mothers their periods of pregnancy should be so spaced that no danger to health from such ailments as tuberculosis could be incurred, and among younger people, all the aspects of family responsibility should be fully considered and appreciated before the arrival of the first baby.
This would tend to promote more security, more affection, and in effect a fuller and happier family life.
Her work in this field, she said, had been justified in many countries since she began it in 1914, and two nations, Japan and India, had adopted birth control officially.

The speaker was introduced to the gathering by Professor Gordon King, Chairman of the Hongkong Family Planning Association, who said there existed at present, considerable demand in the Colony for the Association's advice and help.
